entry.title: [IS-H] Is there any log of NBEW table? (STATU change)
entry.content:

Is there any log of time of change of each movement STATU field?

thank you!

entry.title: SAP RM XFT Centera migration
entry.content:
Dears,

I’m reaching out as I have a customer using SAP Application writing on a Centera. Centera product has to be decommissioned by end of Sept. this year.

We have suggested using an ECS as a new Data Target, which is doable and very easy to deploy. However, customer also wanted to explore the Option of using a Data Domain with his SAP application using NFS protocol.

Customer described his application with the following…

“SAP RM writes via XFT in the PBS Content Share. PBS could also be via NFS on a Data Domain NFS Mount”

My question would be, is there any native SAP tool or XFT itself migrate old Data from Centera (CAS) to Data Domain (NFS) or is this impossible?

Looking forward for your feedback as soon as possible, please.

Best regards

entry.title: BAPI_PATIENT_CREATE
entry.content:
I need to create a patient using BAPI_PATIENT_CREATE.

I‘m using an external development system (Delphi with a special library to address bapi).

My question: In the table PATIENT_DATA doesn‘t address exists an address field but only an address reference PAT_ADDR_NO. To fill the address of a patient there is a table I_ADDRESSES with a corresponding field ADDR_NO. When I create a patient, how can I get a new ADDR_NO? Do I have to fill the field?

And if I want to change the address using BAPI_PATIENT_CHANGE, which fields need to be changed? How to use ADDR_NO in case of a change?

entry.title: Ressource planning based on patient course in WebI
entry.content:
* I am new to Web Intelligence *

I have data on patients who started a certain treatment: Patient IDs and the date of each referral.

I have a list of all appointments ("First meeting with doctor, 60 minutes, 1 month after referral", "Treatment start, 120 minutes, 2 months after referral", etc.) which I need to plot for each patient in order to map the expected ressources needed in the next 3 months.

I have made variables for each part of the treatment in the format as follows:

Date 1st Appt = RelativeDate([Referral Date]; 30)

Date 2nd Appt = RelativeDate([Referral Date]; 60)

Ressources 1st Appt (minutes) = Count (Patient ID) * 60 ForEach ([Date 1st Appt])

Ressources 2nd Appt (minutes) = Count (Patient ID) * 120 ForEach ([Date 2nd Appt])

etc.

I intend to make a graph for the next 3 months where I plot all the minutes against a time dimension on the x-axis with all the dates. It works fine when I plot each appointment on its own (Ressources 1 Appt / Date 1st Appt). However, when I plot all together the dates get "mixed up". Instead of the 2nd appoinment being 30 days later than the 1st appointment, they all land on the same date.

Can someone help me figure out what I am doing wrong. As mentioned, I am quite new with WebI, so I probably just need some basic ideas.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Medical Insurance
entry.content:
Dear All,

our company have a medical department this department is related with dealing with hospital and doctors upon our medical network

as it is a link between company employees and the medical network the cycle is as follow

  • our employee ask the medical department for a medical service
  • the medical department guides the employee to the destination (doctor or hospital)
  • the employee recieves the treatment upon his medical card id
  • there will be a cost recorded by the destination according to the medical service
  • the employee may have a prescription to be issued from the pharmacy
  • there will be a cost recorded by the pharmacy
  • at the end of month there will be a claim sent from medical destinantion to our company
  • the claim is reviewed by the medical department
  • a check is delivered to their bank acount or direct cash to the medical destination

that's a simple scenario for the work cycle

how can i apply this in SAP

please guide me from where i can begin

any materials

any other implemented cycle

thanks

entry.title: Error 'System.NotSupportedException' occurred in CrystalDecisions.CrystalReports.Engine.dll
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

I am using vs2012 to building a window form application with Sap Crystal Report(sdk is "CRforVS_13_0_5.exe"),

sap report 32bit and 64bit runtime file were the same version as sdk,they are was 13.0.5,

but it takes 2~3 seconds to send out the report document to printer,It seems to get an exception in the output window:

*************First printing*************

time1: 2023/7/18 11:48:33

The first opportunity exception of type 'System. NotSupportedException' occurred in CrystalDecisions.CrystalReports. Engine.dll. Thread '<Nameless>' (0x23fc) has exited with a return value of 0 (0x0).

time2: 2023/7/18 11:48:35

*************end*************

It takes 2 seconds to print out(from 11:48:33 to 11:48:35),this action is slowly,I tried several times and all the results were the same,my code as below:

**********************************************************************

Console.WriteLine("time1:"DateTime.Now);

using (hkps_expsheet_main ReportSheetMain = new hkps_expsheet_main())

{

//hkps_expsheet_main is report document

ReportSheetMain.SetDataSource(static_variable.ExpSheet_DT);

this.crystalReportViewer1.ReportSource = ReportSheetMain; //binding report

this.crystalReportViewer1.ToolPanelView = CrystalDecisions.Windows.Forms.ToolPanelViewType.None;

ReportSheetMain.PrintToPrinter(1,true, 1, 1);//auto printing,no preview

}

Console.WriteLine("time2:"DateTime.Now);

***********************************************************************

Is there a solution? thanks

Indka

entry.title: Transforming Healthcare Procurement: Lessons from Our S/4HANA MM Implementation
entry.content:
Introduction

When our healthcare organization decided to migrate from SAP ECC to S/4HANA, the procurement team faced a critical challenge: how do we transform decades-old processes while ensuring uninterrupted supply of life-saving medical supplies? As the SAP MM consultant leading this implementation, I learned valuable lessons that could benefit others embarking on similar journeys.

The Challenge

Healthcare procurement is uniquely complex. Unlike typical manufacturing or retail, we had to contend with:

  • Regulatory compliance: Medical devices and pharmaceuticals require strict traceability
  • Just-in-time criticality: Stock-outs can literally cost lives
  • Complex approval chains: Clinical, financial, and safety approvals needed for different item categories
  • Integration with IS-H: Patient care systems must seamlessly communicate with procurement

Our legacy ECC system had grown organically over 15 years, with customizations layered upon customizations. The procurement cycle averaged 14 days, with 30% of requisitions requiring manual intervention.

Our Approach: Innovation Within S/4HANA

Rather than simply replicating old processes in new technology, we took a transformation approach:

1. Simplified Material Master Data

We reduced material master variants from 12 to 4 by leveraging S/4HANA's Universal Journal. This alone cut data maintenance time by 60%.

Key Innovation: We created a custom Fiori app for clinical staff to request new materials with built-in compliance checks. This reduced incorrect material master requests by 75%.

2. Automated Approval Workflows

Using SAP Workflow and business rules, we automated 70% of approvals:

  • Low-value items (<£500): Auto-approved based on budget holder rules
  • Standard medical supplies: Single-click approval via mobile Fiori
  • High-value/controlled substances: Multi-level workflow with audit trail

Technical Detail: We integrated S/4HANA MM with our IS-H patient safety system, automatically flagging any procurement that could impact patient protocols.

3. Intelligent Inventory Optimization

We implemented SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) alongside MM to predict demand based on:

  • Historical patient admission patterns
  • Seasonal variations (flu season, holiday periods)
  • Planned surgical schedules from IS-H

This reduced emergency orders by 45% while cutting inventory holding costs by £380,000 annually.

4. Supplier Collaboration Portal

Built on SAP Ariba integration, we gave suppliers real-time visibility into:

  • Forecast demand
  • Purchase order status
  • Invoice status and payment schedules

Result: Order-to-delivery time dropped from 8 days to 3 days average.

Implementation Challenges & Solutions

Challenge 1: Change Management with Clinical Staff

Problem: Clinicians are notoriously resistant to new systems that take time away from patient care.

Solution:

  • Created role-specific Fiori launchpads (different for doctors, nurses, department managers)
  • Built "emergency override" function for genuine urgent needs
  • Gamified adoption with department leaderboards showing fastest approval times

Result: 94% user adoption within 3 months (vs. industry average of 65-70%).

Challenge 2: IS-H Integration Complexity

Problem: Our patient management system (IS-H) needed real-time inventory data, but standard integration was causing performance issues.

Solution:

  • Implemented SAP CPI (Cloud Platform Integration) for asynchronous data exchange
  • Created custom BAPI for critical real-time queries (e.g., "Is life-saving drug X in stock?")
  • Built caching layer for frequently accessed data

Technical Note: This architecture pattern is now being replicated across our other S/4HANA modules.

Challenge 3: Regulatory Reporting

Problem: Healthcare regulators require specific procurement reports that don't exist in standard S/4HANA.

Solution:

  • Leveraged SAP Analytics Cloud with custom CDS views
  • Created automated monthly reports pushed to regulatory portal
  • Built audit trail dashboard for compliance team

Measurable Results

After 12 months of go-live:

  • Procurement cycle time: 14 days → 4 days (71% reduction)
  • Cost savings: £380,000 annually in inventory optimization
  • Emergency orders: Reduced by 45%
  • User satisfaction: 8.7/10 (vs. 4.2/10 with old system)
  • Compliance audit findings: Zero critical issues (previously averaged 3-4 per year)
  • Supplier relationships: Net Promoter Score increased from 42 to 78

Key Takeaways for Your S/4HANA Healthcare Journey

1. Don't Just "Lift and Shift"

The power of S/4HANA is in process transformation. Challenge every legacy process before migrating it.

2. Invest Heavily in User Experience

Healthcare professionals are time-poor. If your system adds clicks, they'll find workarounds. Fiori customization was our best ROI investment.

3. Integration Architecture is Critical

Healthcare has more interconnected systems than most industries. Plan your integration strategy before configuration.

4. Build for Compliance from Day One

Retrofitting audit trails and regulatory reports is painful. Include compliance experts in your core team.

5. Phased Approach Works Better Than Big Bang

We went live in three phases:

  • Phase 1: Non-critical supplies (office, housekeeping)
  • Phase 2: Standard medical supplies
  • Phase 3: Controlled substances and high-value equipment

This allowed us to learn and adjust before risking patient care.

What's Next?

We're now exploring:

  • AI-powered demand forecasting: Using SAP AI Business Services to predict supply needs based on patient admission ML models
  • Blockchain for pharmaceutical traceability: Piloting SAP's blockchain solution for controlled substance tracking
  • Predictive maintenance: Integrating medical equipment maintenance schedules with spare parts procuremen

    Questions for the Community

    I'd love to hear from others working on healthcare S/4HANA implementations:

    1. How have you approached IS-H integration in your projects?
    2. What mobile solutions have you found most effective for clinical users?
    3. Have you implemented any AI/ML solutions for procurement optimization?

    Conclusion

    S/4HANA migration in healthcare is complex, but with the right approach, it can transform procurement from a bottleneck into a competitive advantage. The key is balancing innovation with the non-negotiable requirement of patient safety.

    If you're planning a similar implementation, feel free to reach out. I'm always happy to share lessons learned and learn from others' experiences.

  •
